dt: {bc}carried to the utmost point or highest degree {bc}{sx|absolute||}, {sx|total||}

et: Middle English, remote, from Old English {it}ūtera{/it} outer, comparative adjective from {it}ūt{/it} out, adverb {ma}{mat|out|}{/ma}
shortdef: carried to the utmost point or highest degree : absolute, total

dt: {bc}to give public expression to {bc}express in words
{bc}to circulate (something, such as a forged or counterfeit note) as if legal or genuine

pt: {sc}express{/sc} {sc}vent{/sc} {sc}utter{/sc} {sc}voice{/sc} {sc}broach{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} mean to make known what one thinks or feels. {sc}express{/sc} suggests an impulse to reveal in words, gestures, actions, or what one creates or produces.
{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.
{sc}utter{/sc} implies the use of the voice not necessarily in articulate speech.
{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

et: Middle English {it}uttren{/it}, from {it}utter{/it} outside, adverb, from Old English {it}ūtor{/it}, comparative of {it}ūt{/it} out
shortdef: to send forth as a sound
to give utterance to : pronounce, speak
to give public expression to : express in words

dt.t: The wedding was a {it}complete and utter{/it} disaster.
Don't {it}utter a word{/it} about this to anyone.
